member.name: T:X11.EventMask
member.summary: The enumeration specifies the possible event selection.
member.remarks: Clients select event reporting of most events relative to a window.

member.name: T:X11.CrossingMode
member.summary: The enumeration specifies notification modes for Enter and Leave events on a widget.
member.remarks: The mode member is set to indicate whether the focus events are normal focus events ( NotifyNormal,), focus events while grabbed (NotifyWhileGrabbed), focus events when a grab activates (NotifyGrab), or focus events when a grab deactivates (NotifyUngrab).

member.name: F:X11.CrossingMode.NotifyNormal
member.summary: Crossing because of pointer motion.

member.name: F:X11.CrossingMode.NotifyGrab
member.summary: Crossing because a grab is activated.

member.name: F:X11.CrossingMode.NotifyUngrab
member.summary: Crossing because a grab is deactivated.

member.name: F:X11.CrossingMode.NotifyWhileGrabbed
member.summary: Focus changed while under a grab, so the window won't get it back when the grab ends.
member.remarks: Occurs in Alt-Tab, for instance.

member.name: T:X11.GrabDetail
member.summary: The enumeration specifies grab details for Enter and Leave events on a widget.

member.name: F:X11.GrabDetail.NotifyNormal
member.summary: The keyboard is not grabbed while the crossing event occures.

member.name: F:X11.GrabDetail.NotifyGrab
member.summary: The keyboard is grabbed while the crossing event occures.

member.name: F:X11.GrabDetail.NotifyUngrab
member.summary: The keyboard is ungrabbed while the crossing event occures.

member.name: F:X11.GrabDetail.NotifyWhileGrabbed
member.summary: Not used for crossing event.

member.name: T:X11.CrossingDetail
member.summary: The enumeration specifies notification details for Enter and Leave events on a widget.
member.remarks: To understand the notification details: The focus change can, but must not, be initiated by the pointer. The focus change can, but must not affect the window, that currently owns the pointer, or an ancestor or an inferior of the pointer window.

member.name: F:X11.CrossingDetail.NotifyAncestor
member.summary: The window is entered from an ancestor or left towards an ancestor.

member.name: F:X11.CrossingDetail.NotifyVirtual
member.summary: The pointer moves between an ancestor and an inferior of the window.

member.name: F:X11.CrossingDetail.NotifyInferior
member.summary: The window is entered from an inferior or left towards an inferior.

member.name: F:X11.CrossingDetail.NotifyNonlinear
member.summary: The window is entered from or left towards a window which is neither an ancestor nor an inferior.

member.name: F:X11.CrossingDetail.NotifyNonlinearVirtual
member.summary: The pointer moves between two windows which are not ancestors of each other and the window is part of the ancestor chain between one of these windows and their least common ancestor.

member.name: F:X11.CrossingDetail.NotifyPointer
member.summary: The window that is entered or left is a window where the pointer is in, or is an ancestor or an inferior of the window where the pointer is in.

member.name: F:X11.CrossingDetail.NotifyPointerRoot
member.summary: The pointer moves between two windows where one of them is the root windows (of the screen).

member.name: F:X11.CrossingDetail.NotifyDetailNone
member.summary: The pointer moves with root window involved, but NotifyPointerRoot is not suitable/applicable.

member.name: T:X11.XAnyEvent
member.summary: The structure defines members, that are common for all event structures.

member.name: F:X11.XAnyEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XAnyEvent.serial
member.summary: The number of the last request, processed by server.

member.name: F:X11.XAnyEvent.send_event
member.summary: Determine whether the event has been server generated or user requested. Set to true if this came from a SendEvent request.

member.name: F:X11.XAnyEvent.display
member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.name: F:X11.XAnyEvent.window
member.summary: The 'event' window it is reported relative to.

member.name: T:X11.XKeyEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information about keys that logically change state.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.serial
member.summary: The number of the last request, processed by server.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.send_event
member.summary: Determine whether the event has been server generated or user requested. Set to true if this came from a SendEvent request.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.display
member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.window
member.summary: The 'event' window it is reported relative to.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.root
member.summary: The root window that the event occurred on.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.subwindow
member.summary: The child window that the event occurred on.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.time
member.summary: The time when the event was generated - expressed in milliseconds.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.x
member.summary: The pointer x coordinate in event window.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.y
member.summary: The pointer y coordinate in event window.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.x_root
member.summary: The pointer x coordinate relative to root window.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.y_root
member.summary: The pointer x coordinate relative to root window.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.state
member.summary: The key or button mask. Indicate the logical state of the pointer buttons and modifier keys just prior to the event, which is the bitwise inclusive OR of one or more of the button or modifier key masks: Button1Mask, Button2Mask, Button3Mask, Button4Mask, Button5Mask, ShiftMask, LockMask, ControlMask, Mod1Mask, Mod2Mask, Mod3Mask, Mod4Mask, and Mod5Mask.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.keycode
member.summary: The number that represents a physical key on the keyboard. The keycode is an arbitrary representation for any key on the keyboard.

member.name: F:X11.XKeyEvent.same_screen
member.summary: Indicate whether the event window is on the same screen as the root window and can be either true or false.
member.remarks: If true, the event and root windows are on the same screen. If false, the event and root windows are not on the same screen.

member.name: T:X11.XButtonEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information about buttons that logically change state.

member.name: F:X11.XButtonEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XButtonEvent.serial

member.name: F:X11.XButtonEvent.send_event
member.summary: Determine whether the event has been server generated or user requested. Set to true if this came from a SendEvent request.

member.name: F:X11.XButtonEvent.display
member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.name: F:X11.XButtonEvent.window
member.summary: The 'event' window it is reported relative to.

member.name: F:X11.XButtonEvent.root
member.summary: The root window that the event occurred on.

member.name: F:X11.XButtonEvent.subwindow
member.summary: The child window that the event occurred on.

member.name: F:X11.XButtonEvent.time
member.summary: The time when the event was generated - expressed in milliseconds.

member.name: F:X11.XButtonEvent.x
member.summary: The pointer x coordinate in event window.

member.name: F:X11.XButtonEvent.y
member.summary: The pointer y coordinate in event window.

member.name: F:X11.XButtonEvent.x_root
member.summary: The pointer x coordinate relative to root window.

member.remarks: The left button is '1', the middle button is '2', the right button is '3', the wheel up us '4', the wheel down is '5', the Xtra1 is '6' and the Xtra2 is '7'.

member.name: F:X11.XButtonEvent.same_screen
member.summary: Indicate whether the event window is on the same screen as the root window and can be either true or false.
member.remarks: If true, the event and root windows are on the same screen. If false, the event and root windows are not on the same screen.

member.name: T:X11.XCrossingEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information when crosses a window border.
member.remarks: A LeaveNotify event occurs in the window being left and an EnterNotify event occurs in the window being entered.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.serial
member.summary: The number of the last request, processed by server.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.send_event
member.summary: Determine whether the event has been server generated or user requested. Set to true if this came from a SendEvent request.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.display
member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.window
member.summary: The 'event' window it is reported relative to.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.root
member.summary: The root window that the event occurred on.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.subwindow
member.summary: The child window that the event occurred on.
member.remarks: For a LeaveNotify event, if a child of the event window contains the initial position of the pointer, the subwindow component is set to that child. Otherwise, the X server sets the subwindow member to None. For an EnterNotify event, if a child of the event window contains the final pointer position, the subwindow component is set to that child or None. For details see: "http://menehune.opt.wfu.edu/Kokua/Irix_6.5.21_doc_cd/usr/share/Insight/library/SGI_bookshelves/SGI_Developer/books/XLib_PG/sgi_html/re10.html"

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.time
member.summary: The time when the event was generated and is expressed in milliseconds.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.x
member.summary: The pointer x coordinate in event window.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.y
member.summary: The pointer y coordinate in event window.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.x_root
member.summary: The pointer x coordinate relative to root window.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.y_root
member.summary: The pointer x coordinate relative to root window.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.mode
member.summary: Indicate whether the events are normal events, pseudo-motion events when a grab activates, or pseudo-motion events when a grab deactivates.
member.remarks: The X server can set this member to NotifyNormal, NotifyGrab, or NotifyUngrab.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.detail
member.summary: Indicate the notify detail and can be NotifyAncestor, NotifyVirtual, NotifyInferior, NotifyNonlinear, or NotifyNonlinearVirtual.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.same_screen
member.summary: Indicate whether the event window is on the same screen as the root window and can be either true or false.
member.remarks: If true, the event and root windows are on the same screen. If false, the event and root windows are not on the same screen.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.focus
member.summary: Indicate whether the event window is the focus window or an inferior of the focus window. The X server can set this member to either true or false.
member.remarks: If true, the event window is the focus window or an inferior of the focus window. If false, the event window is not the focus window or an inferior of the focus window.

member.name: F:X11.XCrossingEvent.state
member.summary: Indicate the state of the pointer buttons and modifier keys just prior to the event.
member.remarks: The X server can set this member to the bitwise inclusive OR of one or more of the button or modifier key masks: Button1Mask, Button2Mask, Button3Mask, Button4Mask, Button5Mask, ShiftMask, LockMask, ControlMask, Mod1Mask, Mod2Mask, Mod3Mask, Mod4Mask, Mod5Mask.

member.name: T:X11.XFocusChangeEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information when the input focus changes.
member.remarks: The X server can report FocusIn or FocusOut events. The keyboard is always attached to some window (typically, the root window or a top-level window), which is called the focus window. The focus window and the position of the pointer determine the window that receives keyboard input. Clients may need to know when the input focus changes to control highlighting of areas on the screen.

member.name: F:X11.XFocusChangeEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XFocusChangeEvent.serial
member.summary: The number of the last request, processed by server.

member.name: F:X11.XFocusChangeEvent.send_event
member.summary: Determine whether the event has been server generated or user requested. Set to true if this came from a SendEvent request.

member.name: F:X11.XFocusChangeEvent.display
member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.name: F:X11.XFocusChangeEvent.window
member.summary: The 'event' window it is reported relative to.

member.name: F:X11.XFocusChangeEvent.mode
member.summary: Indicate whether the focus events are normal focus events, focus events while grabbed, focus events when a grab activates, or focus events when a grab deactivates.
member.remarks: The X server can set the mode member to NotifyNormal (0), NotifyWhileGrabbed (3), NotifyGrab (1), or NotifyUngrab (2). All FocusOut events caused by a window unmap are generated after any UnmapNotify event; however, the X protocol does not constrain the ordering of FocusOut events with respect to generated EnterNotify, LeaveNotify, VisibilityNotify, and Expose events.

member.name: F:X11.XFocusChangeEvent.detail
member.summary: The focus change details according the affected window.

member.name: F:X11.XKeymapEvent.key_vector0
member.summary: The bit vector of the keyboard for keys 0 (zero-based) to 7.
member.remarks: Each bit set to 1 indicates that the corresponding key is currently pressed. The vector is represented as 32 bytes. Byte N (from 0) contains the bits for keys 8N to 8N + 7 with the least-significant bit in the byte representing key 8N.

member.name: T:X11.XExposeEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information when the contents of window regions have been lost.

member.name: F:X11.XExposeEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.summary: The number of the last request, processed by server.

member.summary: Determine whether the event has been server generated or user requested. Set to true if this came from a SendEvent request.

member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.summary: The upper-left corner coordinates of the rectangle relative to the window's origin.

member.name: F:X11.XExposeEvent.y
member.summary: The upper-left corner coordinates of the rectangle relative to the window's origin.

member.name: F:X11.XExposeEvent.width
member.summary: The size (extent) of the rectangle.

member.name: F:X11.XExposeEvent.height
member.summary: The size (extent) of the rectangle.

member.name: F:X11.XExposeEvent.count
member.summary: The number of Expose events that are to follow.
member.remarks: If count is zero, no more Expose events follow for this window. However, if count is nonzero, at least that number of Expose events (and possibly more) follow for this window. Simple applications that do not want to optimize redisplay by distinguishing between subareas of its window can just ignore all Expose events with nonzero counts and perform full redisplays on events with zero counts.

member.name: T:X11.XGraphicsExposeEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information when a destination region could not be computed during certain graphics requests: XCopyArea() or XCopyPlane().
member.remarks: The X server generates this event whenever a destination region could not be computed due to an obscured or out-of-bounds source region. In addition, the X server guarantees to report contiguously all of the regions exposed by some graphics request (for example, copying an area of a drawable to a destination drawable).

member.name: F:X11.XGraphicsExposeEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XGraphicsExposeEvent.serial
member.summary: The number of the last request, processed by server.

member.summary: Determine whether the event has been server generated or user requested. Set to true if this came from a SendEvent request.

member.name: F:X11.XGraphicsExposeEvent.display
member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.name: F:X11.XGraphicsExposeEvent.drawable
member.summary: The drawable of the destination region on which the graphics request was to be performed.

member.name: F:X11.XGraphicsExposeEvent.x
member.summary: The upper-left corner coordinates of the rectangle relative to the window's origin.

member.name: F:X11.XGraphicsExposeEvent.y
member.summary: The upper-left corner coordinates of the rectangle relative to the window's origin.

member.name: F:X11.XGraphicsExposeEvent.width
member.summary: The size (extent) of the rectangle.

member.name: F:X11.XGraphicsExposeEvent.height
member.summary: The size (extent) of the rectangle.

member.name: F:X11.XGraphicsExposeEvent.count
member.summary: he number of GraphicsExpose events to follow.
member.remarks: If count is zero, no more GraphicsExpose events follow for this window. However, if count is nonzero, at least that number of GraphicsExpose events (and possibly more) are to follow for this window.

member.name: F:X11.XGraphicsExposeEvent.major_code
member.summary: The core is CopyArea or CopyPlane.

member.name: F:X11.XGraphicsExposeEvent.minor_code
member.summary: Not defined in the core.

member.name: T:X11.XNoExposeEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information when a destination region could not be computed during certain graphics requests: XCopyArea() or XCopyPlane().
member.remarks: The X server generates a NoExpose event whenever a graphics request that might produce a GraphicsExpose event does not produce any. In other words, the client is really asking for a GraphicsExpose event but instead receives a NoExpose event.

member.summary: The core is CopyArea or CopyPlane.

member.summary: Not defined in the core.

member.name: T:X11.XVisibilityEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information when the visibility of the specified window changes.
member.remarks: A region of a window is visible if someone looking at the screen can actually see it. The X server generates this event whenever the visibility changes state. However, this event is never generated for windows whose class is InputOnly .

member.summary: The 'event' window it is reported relative to.

member.name: F:X11.XVisibilityEvent.state
member.summary: The state of the window's visibility and can be VisibilityUnobscured, VisibilityPartiallyObscured, or VisibilityFullyObscured.

member.name: T:X11.XMapRequestEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information about a different client's desire to map windows.
member.remarks: A window is considered mapped when a map window request completes. The X server generates this event whenever a different client initiates a map window request on an unmapped window whose override_redirect member is set to false. Clients initiate map window requests by calling XMapWindow(), XMapRaised(), or XMapSubwindows().

member.summary: The window that was reparented.

member.summary: The reparented window's x coordinates relative to the new parent window's origin and define the upper-left outer corner of the reparented window.

member.name: F:X11.XReparentEvent.y
member.summary: The reparented window's y coordinates relative to the new parent window's origin and define the upper-left outer corner of the reparented window.

member.name: F:X11.XReparentEvent.override_redirect
member.summary: Set to the override_redirect attribute of the window specified by the window member. Window manager clients normally should ignore this window if the override_redirect member is true.

member.name: T:X11.XConfigureEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information about actual changes to a window's state, such as size, position, border, and stacking order.
member.remarks: Called whenever one of the folloeing configure window requests is completed: * A window's size, position, border, and/or stacking order is reconfigured by calling XConfigureWindow(). * The window's position in the stacking order is changed by calling XLowerWindow(), XRaiseWindow(), or XRestackWindows(). * A window is moved by calling XMoveWindow(). * A window's size is changed by calling XResizeWindow(). * A window's size and location is changed by calling XMoveResizeWindow(). * A window is mapped and its position in the stacking order is changed by calling XMapRaised(). * A window's border width is changed by calling XSetWindowBorderWidth().

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureEvent.serial
member.summary: The number of the last request, processed by server.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureEvent.send_event
member.summary: Determine whether the event has been server generated or user requested. Set to true if this came from a SendEvent request.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureEvent.display
member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureEvent.xevent
member.summary: Either the reparented window or to the old or the new parent, depending on whether StructureNotify or SubstructureNotify was selected.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureEvent.window
member.summary: The window that had a size, position, border, stacking or order change.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureEvent.x
member.summary: The configured window's x coordinates relative to the new parent window's origin - the upper-left outer corner of the reparented window.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureEvent.y
member.summary: The configured window's y coordinates relative to the new parent window's origin - the upper-left outer corner of the reparented window.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureEvent.width
member.summary: The configured window's width, excluding the border.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureEvent.height
member.summary: The configured window's height, excluding the border.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureEvent.border_width
member.summary: The configured window's border width.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureEvent.above
member.summary: The sibling window. Used for stacking operations.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureEvent.override_redirect
member.summary: Set to the override_redirect attribute of the window specified by the window member. Window manager clients normally should ignore this window if the override_redirect member is true.

member.name: T:X11.XGravityEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information when a window is moved because of a change in the size of its parent.
member.remarks: The X server generates this event whenever a client application actually moves a child window as a result of resizing its parent by calling XConfigureWindow(), XMoveResizeWindow(), or XResizeWindow().

member.name: F:X11.XGravityEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XGravityEvent.serial

member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.summary: Either the window that was moved or to its parent, depending on whether StructureNotify or SubstructureNotify was selected.

member.name: F:X11.XGravityEvent.window
member.summary: The child window that is moved because of a size change of it's parent.

member.name: F:X11.XGravityEvent.x
member.summary: The window's x coordinates relative to the new parent window's origin - the upper-left outer corner of the reparented window.

member.name: F:X11.XGravityEvent.y
member.summary: The window's y coordinates relative to the new parent window's origin - the upper-left outer corner of the reparented window.

member.summary: The structure contains information about another client's attempts to change the size of a window.
member.remarks: The X server generates this event whenever some other client attempts to change the size of the specified window by calling XConfigureWindow(), XResizeWindow(), or XMoveResizeWindow().

member.name: F:X11.XResizeRequestEvent.height
member.summary: The window's height, excluding the border.

member.name: T:X11.XConfigureRequestEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information when a different client initiates a configure window request on any child of a specified window.
member.remarks: The configure window request attempts to reconfigure a window's size, position, border, and stacking order. The X server generates this event whenever a different client initiates a configure window request on a window by calling XConfigureWindow(), XLowerWindow(), XRaiseWindow(), XMapRaised(), XMoveResizeWindow(), XMoveWindow(), XResizeWindow(), XRestackWindows(), or XSetWindowBorderWidth().

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureRequestEvent.type

member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureRequestEvent.parent
member.summary: The parent window.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureRequestEvent.window
member.summary: The window that had a size, position, border, stacking or order reconfiguration.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureRequestEvent.x
member.summary: The requested window's x coordinates relative to the parent window's origin - the upper-left outer corner of the window.

member.summary: The requested window's y coordinates relative to the parent window's origin - the upper-left outer corner of the window.

member.summary: The requested window's width, excluding the border.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureRequestEvent.height

member.summary: The requested window's border width.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureRequestEvent.above
member.summary: The sibling window, this window is above, or None if not reported.

member.name: F:X11.XConfigureRequestEvent.value_mask
member.summary: Indicate which components were specified in the ConfigureWindow protocol request.

member.name: T:X11.XCirculateEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information when a window changes its position in the stack.
member.remarks: The X server generates this event type whenever a window is actually restacked as a result of a client application calling XCirculateSubwindows(), XCirculateSubwindowsUp(), or XCirculateSubwindowsDown().

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateEvent.serial
member.summary: The number of the last request, processed by server.

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateEvent.send_event
member.summary: Determine whether the event has been server generated or user requested. Set to true if this came from a SendEvent request.

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateEvent.display
member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateEvent.xevent
member.summary: Either the restacked window or to its parent, depending on whether StructureNotify or SubstructureNotify was selected.

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateEvent.window
member.summary: The window that was restacked.

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateEvent.place
member.summary: The window's position after the restack occurs and is either PlaceOnTop or PlaceOnBottom.
member.remarks: If it is PlaceOnTop, the window is now on top of all siblings. If it is PlaceOnBottom, the window is now below all siblings.

member.name: T:X11.XCirculateRequestEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information when another client initiates a circulate window request on a specified window.
member.remarks: The X server generates this event type whenever a client initiates a circulate window request on a window and a subwindow actually needs to be restacked. The client initiates a circulate window request on the window by calling XCirculateSubwindows(), XCirculateSubwindowsUp(), or XCirculateSubwindowsDown().

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateRequestEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateRequestEvent.serial
member.summary: The number of the last request, processed by server.

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateRequestEvent.send_event
member.summary: Determine whether the event has been server generated or user requested. Set to true if this came from a SendEvent request.

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateRequestEvent.display
member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateRequestEvent.parent
member.summary: The parent window.

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateRequestEvent.window
member.summary: The window that is to be restacked.

member.name: F:X11.XCirculateRequestEvent.place
member.summary: The requested window's position after the restack occurs and is either PlaceOnTop or PlaceOnBottom.
member.remarks: If it is PlaceOnTop, the window is now on top of all siblings. If it is PlaceOnBottom, the window is now below all siblings.

member.summary: The structure contains information about the client losing ownership of a selection.

member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.summary: The window that was specified by the current owner (the owner losing the selection) in its XSetSelectionOwner() call.

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionClearEvent.selection
member.summary: The atom that names the selection.

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionClearEvent.time
member.summary: The last change time recorded for the selection.

member.name: T:X11.XSelectionRequestEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information about a selection request to the owner of a selection.
member.remarks: The X server generates this event whenever a client requests a selection conversion by calling XConvertSelection() for the owned selection.

member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionRequestEvent.serial

member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.summary: The window that was specified by the current owner in its XSetSelectionOwner() call.

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionRequestEvent.requestor
member.summary: The window requesting the selection.

member.summary: The atom that names the selection.

member.summary: The window requesting the selection.

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionRequestEvent.property
member.summary: The property name or None.

member.summary: The timestamp or CurrentTime value from the ConvertSelection request.

member.name: T:X11.XSelectionEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information in response to a ConvertSelection protocol request when there is no owner for the selection.
member.remarks: When there is an owner, it should be generated by the owner of the selection by using XSendEvent(). The owner of a selection should send this event to a requestor when a selection has been converted and stored as a property or when a selection conversion could not be performed (which is indicated by setting the property member to None).

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionEvent.serial
member.summary: The number of the last request, processed by server.

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionEvent.send_event
member.summary: Determine whether the event has been server generated or user requested. Set to true if this came from a SendEvent request.

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionEvent.display
member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionEvent.requestor
member.summary: The window associated with the requestor of the selection.

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionEvent.selection
member.summary: The atom that names the selection. For example, PRIMARY is used for the primary selection.

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionEvent.target
member.summary: The atom that indicates the converted type. For example, PIXMAP is used for a pixmap.

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionEvent.property
member.summary: None.

member.name: F:X11.XSelectionEvent.time
member.summary: The time the conversion took place and can be a timestamp or CurrentTime.

member.name: T:X11.XColormapEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information when the colormap changes and when a colormap is installed or uninstalled.
member.remarks:
The X server generates this event type whenever a client application:
[1] Changes the colormap member of the XSetWindowAttributes structure by calling XChangeWindowAttributes(), XFreeColormap(), or XSetWindowColormap().
[2] Installs or uninstalls the colormap by calling XInstallColormap() or XUninstallColormap().

member.name: F:X11.XColormapEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XColormapEvent.serial
member.summary: The number of the last request, processed by server.

member.name: F:X11.XColormapEvent.send_event
member.summary: Determine whether the event has been server generated or user requested. Set to true if this came from a SendEvent request.

member.name: F:X11.XColormapEvent.display
member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.name: F:X11.XColormapEvent.window
member.summary: The window whose associated colormap is changed, installed, or uninstalled.

member.name: F:X11.XColormapEvent.colormap
member.summary: The colormap associated with the window for a colormap that is changed, installed, or uninstalled. None for a colormap that is changed by a call to XFreeColormap().

member.name: F:X11.XColormapEvent.c_new
member.summary: Indicate whether the colormap for the specified window was changed or installed or uninstalled and can be true or false. If it is true, the colormap was changed. If it is false, the colormap was installed or uninstalled.

member.name: F:X11.XColormapEvent.state
member.summary: Indicate whether the colormap is installed or uninstalled and can be ColormapInstalled or ColormapUninstalled.

member.name: T:X11.XMappingEvent
member.summary: The structure contains information when a client gets mapped.
member.remarks:
There is no mechanism to express disinterest in this event. The X server generates this event type whenever a client application successfully calls:
[1] XSetModifierMapping() to indicate which KeyCodes are to be used as modifiers.
[2] XChangeKeyboardMapping() to change the keyboard mapping.
[3] XSetPointerMapping() to set the pointer mapping.

member.name: F:X11.XMappingEvent.type
member.summary: The event type identifier. All event structures provide this type enum at the first position in memory.

member.name: F:X11.XMappingEvent.serial
member.summary: The number of the last request, processed by server.

member.name: F:X11.XMappingEvent.send_event
member.summary: Determine whether the event has been server generated or user requested. Set to true if this came from a SendEvent request.

member.name: F:X11.XMappingEvent.display
member.summary: The display the event was read from.

member.name: F:X11.XMappingEvent.window
member.summary: Not used but is present to aid some toolkits.

member.name: F:X11.XMappingEvent.request
member.summary: Indicate the kind of mapping change that occurred and can be MappingModifier, MappingKeyboard, MappingPointer.
member.remarks: If it is MappingModifier, the modifier mapping was changed. If it is MappingKeyboard, the keyboard mapping was changed. If it is MappingPointer, the pointer button mapping was changed.

member.name: F:X11.XMappingEvent.first_keycode
member.summary: Used only if the request member was set to MappingKeyboard. The first number in the range of the altered mapping.

member.name: F:X11.XMappingEvent.count
member.summary: Used only if the request member was set to MappingKeyboard. The number of keycodes altered.

member.name: M:X11.X11Utils.StringToSByteArray(System.String)
member.summary: Convert a C# string (2 byte (0...65.536) character array) into a byte (1 byte (0...255) character) array.
member.param: The C# string to convert.

member.summary: Extract a sub-array from a byte (1 byte (0...255) character) array.

The index of the first character to extract.

member.summary: Determine the index of indicated character within a byte (1 byte (0...255) character) array.

The mask string to compare to. Accepts '?' as single-char joker and '*' as multi-char joker.

member.name: T:X11.Xpmlib
member.summary: The class wraps the native code libXpm library.

member.name: M:X11.Xpmlib.XpmCreatePixmapFromData(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr@,System.IntPtr@,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: Creates X images using XpmCreateImageFromData () and thus returns the same errors. In addition on success it then creates the related pixmaps, using XPutImage, which are returned to pixmap and shapemask if not NULL, and finally destroys the created images using XDestroyImage ().
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
Specifies which screen the pixmap is created on.
Specifies the location of the data.
Returns the pixmap which is created.
Returns the shape mask pixmap which is created if the color None is used.
SSpecifies the location of a structure to get and store information (or NULL).
member.returns: If the file cannot be opened it returns XpmOpenFailed. If the file can be opened but does not contain valid XPM data, it returns XpmFileInvalid. If insufficient working storage is allocated, it returns XpmNoMemory.
member.remarks: Do not forget to free the returned pixmaps, the colors, and possibly the data returned into the XpmAttributes structure when done.

member.name: M:X11.XRenderLib.XRenderQueryExtension(System.IntPtr,X11.TInt@,X11.TInt@)
member.summary: Determine whether render extension is available on display.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The first event number used by the extension (note that Render currently uses no events).
he first error number used by the extension.
member.returns: True if the Render extension is available on display, or false otherwise.

member.name: M:X11.XRenderLib.XRenderQueryVersion(System.IntPtr,X11.TInt@,X11.TInt@)
member.summary: Discover the current Render version number.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The major version number less than or equal to the library version numbers RENDER_MAJOR.
The minor version number less than or equal to the library version numbers RENDER_MAJOR.
member.returns: Zero if the Render extension is not present or soome error occurred while attempting to discover the current Render version number, or 1 otherwise.

member.name: M:X11.XRenderLib.XRenderQueryFormats(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Fetch the available PictFormat information from the X server.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
member.returns: 1 if the available PictFormat information has been fetched successfully from the X server, or 0 otherwise.

member.name: M:X11.XRenderLib.XRenderQuerySubpixelOrder(System.IntPtr,X11.TInt)
member.summary: Investigate the subpixel order.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The screen number, that specifies the appropriate screen on the X server.
member.returns: The subpixel order.
member.remarks: Applications interested in the geometry of the elements making up a single pixel on the screen should use XRenderQuerySubpixelOrder and do not cache the return value. XRenderSetSubpixelOrder is used by the XRandR library to update the value stored by Xrender when the subpixel order changes as a result of screen reconfiguration.

member.name: M:X11.XRenderLib.XRenderSetSubpixelOrder(System.IntPtr,X11.TInt,System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the subpixel order.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The screen number, that specifies the appropriate screen on the X server.
The subpixel order to set.
member.returns: Returns true on success, or false otherwise.
member.remarks: Applications interested in the geometry of the elements making up a single pixel on the screen should use XRenderQuerySubpixelOrder and do not cache the return value. XRenderSetSubpixelOrder is used by the XRandR library to update the value stored by Xrender when the subpixel order changes as a result of screen reconfiguration.

member.name: M:X11.XRenderLib._XRenderCreatePicture(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.XRenderCreatePictureValueMask,X11.XRenderLib.XRenderPictureAttributes@)
member.summary: Create a picture for indicated drawable and specified format. Any values specified in 'pXRenderPictureAttributes' and 'valuemask' are used in replace of the default values.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The drawable to create a picture for
The desired format of the picture.

Specifies which picture attributes are defined in the pXRenderPictureAttributes argument. This mask is the bitwise nclusive OR of the valid attribute mask bits. If valuemask is zero, the attributes are ignored and are not referenced.
Specifies the structure from which the attribute values (as specified by the value mask) are to be taken.
member.returns: The picture for indicated drawable and specified format on success, or IntPtr.Zero otherwise.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XOpenDisplay(System.String)
member.summary: Open a connection to the X server that controls a display.
member.param: Display name syntax is: hostname:number.screen_number; like: dual-headed:0.1; or empty sting for default.
member.returns: The display pointer on success, or IntPtr.Zero otherwise.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XCloseDisplay(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Close a connection to the X server that controls a display.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XLockDisplay(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Locks out all other threads from using the specified display. Other threads attempting to use the display will block until the display is unlocked by this thread. This function has no effect unless Xlib was successfully initialized for threads using .
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
member.remarks: Nested calls to work correctly; the display will not actually be unlocked until has been called the same number of times as .

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XUnlockDisplay(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Allows other threads to use the specified display again. Any threads, that have been blocked on the display, are allowed to continue. This function has no effect unless Xlib was successfully initialized for threads using .
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
member.remarks: Nested locking works correctly; if has been called multiple times by a thread, then must be called an equal number of times before the display is actually unlocked.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XMoveWindow(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.TInt,X11.TInt)
member.summary: Move specified window to the specified x and y coordinates, but do not change the window's size, raise the window, or change the mapping state of the window.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window to move.
The new x coordinate, which defines the new location of the top-left pixel of the window's border or the window itself if it has no border.
The new y coordinate, which defines the new location of the top-left pixel of the window's border or the window itself if it has no border.

The window to resize.
The new width, which is the interior dimensions of the window after the call completes.
The new heigth, which is the interior dimensions of the window after the call completes.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XMoveResizeWindow(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.TInt,X11.TInt,X11.TUint,X11.TUint)
member.summary: Change the size and location of the specified window without raising it.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window to move and resize.
The new x coordinate, which defines the new location of the top-left pixel of the window's border or the window itself if it has no border.
The new y coordinate, which defines the new location of the top-left pixel of the window's border or the window itself if it has no border.
The new width, which is the interior dimensions of the window after the call completes.
The new heigth, which is the interior dimensions of the window after the call completes.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XReparentWindow(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.TInt,X11.TInt)
member.summary: Change the parent window of the specified window.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window to reparent.
The parent window.
The new x coordinate, which defines the new location of the top-left pixel of the window inside the new parent window.
The new y coordinate, which defines the new location of the top-left pixel of the window inside the new parent window.
member.remarks: If the specified window is mapped, XReparentWindow() automatically performs an UnmapWindow request on it, removes it from its current position in the hierarchy, and inserts it as the child of the specified parent. The window is placed in the stacking order on top with respect to sibling windows. * After reparenting the specified window, XReparentWindow() causes the X server to generate a ReparentNotify event. The override_redirect member returned in this event is set to the window's corresponding attribute. Window manager clients usually should ignore this window if this member is set to True. Finally, if the specified window was originally mapped, the X server automatically performs a MapWindow request on it. * The X server performs normal exposure processing on formerly obscured windows. The X server might not generate Expose events for regions from the initial UnmapWindow request that are immediately obscured by the final MapWindow request.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XMapWindow(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Map the window and all of its subwindows that have had map requests to a display.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window to map.
member.remarks: Take care for a window width/height grater than 0!

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XMapRaised(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The XMapRaised() function essentially is similar to XMapWindow() in that it maps the window and all of its subwindows that have had map requests. However, it also raises the specified window to the top of the stack. For additional information, see XMapWindow().
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window to map.
member.remarks: To activate a shell window (e.g. a XrwTransientShell) send _NET_ACTIVE_WINDOW event to root window.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XUnmapWindow(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Unmap the specified window and causes the X server to generate an UnmapNotify event. If the specified window is already unmapped, XUnmapWindow () has no effect. Normal exposure processing on formerly obscured windows is performed. Any child window will no longer be visible until another map call is made on the parent. In other words, the subwindows are still mapped but are not visible until the parent is mapped. Unmapping a window will generate Expose events on windows that were formerly obscured by it.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window to unmap.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XRaiseWindow(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The XRaiseWindow() function raises the specified window to the top of the stack so that no sibling window obscures it.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window to raise.
member.remarks: Raising a mapped window may generate Expose events for the window and any mapped subwindows that were formerly obscured.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XCirculateSubwindows(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.TInt)
member.summary: The XRaiseWindow() function circulates children of the specified window in the specified direction.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window who's children are to circulate.
Specifies the direction (up or down) to circulate the child window. It can be passed RaiseLowest (0) or LowerHighest (1).
member.remarks: To activate a shell window (e.g. a XrwTransientShell) send _NET_ACTIVE_WINDOW event to root window.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XCreateSimpleWindow(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.TInt,X11.TInt,X11.TUint,X11.TUint,X11.TUint,X11.TPixel,X11.TPixel)
member.summary: Create an unmapped subwindow for a specified parent window, returns the window ID of the created window, and causes the X server to generate a CreateNotify event. The created window is placed on top in the stacking order with respect to siblings.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The parent window.
Tthe x coordinate, which is the top-left outside corner of the window's borders and relative to the inside of the parent window's borders.
Tthe y coordinate, which is the top-left outside corner of the window's borders and relative to the inside of the parent window's borders.
The width, which is the created window's inside dimensions and do not include the created window's borders.
The height, which is the created window's inside dimensions and do not include the created window's borders.
The outside (surrounding) border width of the created window in pixels.
The border pixel value of the window.
The background pixel value of the window.
member.returns: The window ID of the created window on success, or IntPtr.Zero otherwise.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XChangeWindowAttributes(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.XWindowAttributeMask,X11.XSetWindowAttributes@)
member.summary: Change the window attributes in the XSetWindowAttributes.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The parent window.

Specifies which window attributes are defined in the attributes argument. This mask is the bitwise inclusive OR of the valid attribute mask bits. If valuemask is zero, the attributes are ignored and are not referenced. The values and restrictions are the same as for XCreateWindow().
Specifies the structure from which the attribute values (as specified by the value mask) are to be taken.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XCreateWindow(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.TInt,X11.TInt,X11.TUint,X11.TUint,X11.TUint,X11.TInt,X11.XWindowClass,System.IntPtr,X11.XWindowAttributeMask,X11.XSetWindowAttributes@)
member.summary: Create an unmapped subwindow for a specified parent window, returns the window ID of the created window, and causes the X server to generate a CreateNotify event. The created window is placed on top in the stacking order with respect to siblings.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The parent window.
The x coordinate, which is the top-left outside corner of the window's borders and relative to the inside of the parent window's borders.
The y coordinate, which is the top-left outside corner of the window's borders and relative to the inside of the parent window's borders.
The width, which is the created window's inside dimensions and do not include the created window's borders.
The height, which is the created window's inside dimensions and do not include the created window's borders.
The outside (surrounding) border width of the created window in pixels.
The window's depth. A depth of CopyFromParent means the depth is taken from the parent.
The created window's class. You can pass InputOutput, InputOnly, or CopyFromParent. A class of CopyFromParent means the class is taken from the parent.
The visual type. A visual of CopyFromParent means the visual type is taken from the parent.

Specifies which window attributes are defined in the attributes argument. This mask is the bitwise inclusive OR of the valid attribute mask bits. If valuemask is zero, the attributes are ignored and are not referenced.
The structure from which the values (as specified by the value mask) are to be taken. The value mask should have the appropriate bits set to indicate which attributes have been set in the structure.
member.returns: The window ID of the created window on success, or IntPtr.Zero otherwise.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XInternAtom(System.IntPtr,X11.TChar[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Return the atom identifier associated with the specified atom_name string. If onlyIfExists is False, the atom is created if it does not exist. Therefore, XInternAtom() can return IntPtr.Zero. If the atom name is not in the Host Portable Character Encoding, the result is implementation dependent. Uppercase and lowercase matter; the strings "thing", "Thing", and "thinG" all designate different atoms. The atom will remain defined even after the client's connection closes. It will become undefined only when the last connection to the X server closes.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The [] name of the atom to return.
Specifies a value that indicates whether the atom must be created, if it doesn't exist.
member.returns: A to the atom on success, or IntPtr.Zero otherwise.
member.remarks: Define the atomName including terminating NULL like: X11Utils.StringToSByteArray ("WM_DELETE_WINDOW\0")

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XInternAtom(System.IntPtr,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Return the atom identifier associated with the specified atomName string. If onlyIfExists is False, the atom is created if it does not exist. Therefore, XInternAtom() can return IntPtr.Zero. If the atom name is not in the Host Portable Character Encoding, the result is implementation dependent. Uppercase and lowercase matter; the strings "thing", "Thing", and "thinG" all designate different atoms. The atom will remain defined even after the client's connection closes. It will become undefined only when the last connection to the X server closes.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The name of the atom to return.
Specifies a boolean value that indicates whether the atom must be created, if it doesn't exist.
member.returns: A pointer to the atom on success, or IntPtr.Zero otherwise.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XGetAtomName(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Get the name associated with the specified atom.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The atom for the property name to return.
member.returns: The name associated with the specified atom.
member.remarks: To free the resulting string, call XFree().

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XSetWMProtocols(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr@,X11.TInt)
member.summary: Replace the WM_PROTOCOLS property on the specified window with the list of atoms specified by the protocols argument. If the property does not already exist, XSetWMProtocols() sets the WM_PROTOCOLS property on the specified window to the list of atoms specified by the protocols argument. The property is stored with a type of ATOM and a format of 32. If it cannot intern the WM_PROTOCOLS atom, XSetWMProtocols() returns a zero status. Otherwise, it returns a nonzero status.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window to replace the the WM_PROTOCOLS property.
Thelist of protocols as atom pointer.
The number of protocols in the list.
member.returns: Nonzero on success, or zero otherwise.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XStoreName(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.SByte[])
member.summary: Assign the indicated name to the specified window. A window manager can display the window name in some prominent place, such as the title bar, to allow users to identify windows easily. Some window managers may display a window's name in the window's icon, although they are encouraged to use the window's icon name if one is provided by the application.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window to set the name for.
The [] name to set for the window.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XGrabPointer(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.TBoolean,X11.TInt,X11.TInt,X11.TInt,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.TTime)
member.summary: Actively grab control of the pointer. Further pointer events are reported only to the grabbing client. XGrabPointer() overrides any active pointer grab by this client.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window that shold grab the pointer.
Specify whether the pointer events are to be reported as usual or reported with respect to the grab window if selected by the event mask.
Specify which pointer events are reported to the client. The mask is the bitwise inclusive OR of the valid pointer event mask bits.
Specify further processing of pointer events. You can pass GrabModeSync or GrabModeAsync.
Specify further processing of keyboard events. You can pass GrabModeSync or GrabModeAsync.
Specify the window to confine the pointer in or None.
Specify the cursor that is to be displayed during the grab or None.
Specify the time. You can pass either a timestamp or CurrentTime.
member.returns: Returns GrabSuccess if the grab was successful.
member.remarks: * If ownerEvents is false, all generated pointer events are reported with respect to x11window and are reported only if selected by eventMask. If ownerEvents is true and if a generated pointer event would normally be reported to this client, it is reported as usual. Otherwise, the event is reported with respect to the x11window and is reported only if selected by eventMask. For either value of ownerEvents, unreported events are discarded. * If the pointerMode is GrabModeAsync, pointer event processing continues as usual. If the pointer is currently frozen by this client, the processing of events for the pointer is resumed. If the pointerMode is GrabModeSync, the state of the pointer, as seen by client applications, appears to freeze, and the X server generates no further pointer events until the grabbing client calls XAllowEvents() or until the pointer grab is released. Actual pointer changes are not lost while the pointer is frozen; they are simply queued in the server for later processing. * If the keyboardMode is GrabModeAsync, keyboard event processing is unaffected by activation of the grab. If the keyboardMode is GrabModeSync, the state of the keyboard, as seen by client applications, appears to freeze, and the X server generates no further keyboard events until the grabbing client calls XAllowEvents() or until the pointer grab is released. Actual keyboard changes are not lost while the pointer is frozen; they are simply queued in the server for later processing. * If a cursor is specified, it is displayed regardless of what window the pointer is in. If None is specified, the normal cursor for that window is displayed when the pointer is in x11window or one of its subwindows; otherwise, the cursor for x11window is displayed. * If a confineTo window is specified, the pointer is restricted to stay contained in that window. The confineTo window need have no relationship to the x11window. If the pointer is not initially in the confineTo window, it is warped automatically to the closest edge just before the grab activates and enter/leave events are generated as usual. If the confineTo window is subsequently reconfigured, the pointer is warped automatically, as necessary, to keep it contained in the window. * The time argument allows you to avoid certain circumstances that come up if applications take a long time to respond or if there are long network delays. Consider a situation where you have two applications, both of which normally grab the pointer when clicked on. If both applications specify the timestamp from the event, the second application may wake up faster and successfully grab the pointer before the first application. The first application then will get an indication that the other application grabbed the pointer before its request was processed.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XUngrabPointer(System.IntPtr,X11.TTime)
member.summary: Release the pointer and any queued events if this client has been actively grabbed the pointer from XGrabPointer(), XGrabButton(), or from a normal button press.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
Specify the time. You can pass either a timestamp or CurrentTime.
member.remarks: XUngrabPointer() does not release the pointer if the specified time is earlier than the last-pointer-grab time or is later than the current X server time. It also generates EnterNotify and LeaveNotify events. The X server performs an UngrabPointer request automatically if the event window or confineTo window for an active pointer grab becomes not viewable or if window reconfiguration causes the confineTo window to lie completely outside the boundaries of the root window.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XtGrabKeyboard(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.TBoolean,X11.TInt,X11.TInt,X11.TTime)
member.summary: Actively grab control of the keyboard and generates FocusIn and FocusOut events. Further key events are reported only to the grabbing client. XGrabKeyboard() overrides any active keyboard grab by this client.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window that shold grab the keyboard.

Specifies a Boolean value that indicates whether the keyboard events are to be reported as usual. If ownerEvents is false, all generated key events are reported with respect to x11window. If ownerEvents is true and if a generated key event would normally be reported to this client, it is reported normally; otherwise, the event is reported with respect to the x11window. Both KeyPress and KeyRelease events are always reported, independent of any event selection made by the client.

Specifies further processing of pointer events. GrabModeSync or GrabModeAsync can be passed. If pointerMode is GrabModeAsync, pointer event processing is unaffected by activation of the grab. If pointerMode is GrabModeSync, the state of the pointer (as seen by client applications) appears to freeze, and the X server generates no further pointer events until the grabbing client issues a releasing XAllowEvents() call or until the keyboard grab is released. Actual pointer changes are not lost while the pointer is frozen; they are simply queued in the server for later processing.

Specifies further processing of keyboard events. You can pass GrabModeSync or GrabModeAsync. If the keyboardMode argument is GrabModeAsync, keyboard event processing continues as usual. If the keyboard is currently frozen by this client, then processing of keyboard events is resumed. If the keyboardMode argument is GrabModeSync, the state of the keyboard(as seen by client applications) appears to freeze, and the X server generates no further keyboard events until the grabbing client issues a releasing XAllowEvents() call or until the keyboard grab is released. Actual keyboard changes are not lost while the keyboard is frozen; they are simply queued in the server for later processing.
Specifies the time. You can pass either a timestamp or CurrentTime.
member.remarks: If the keyboard is actively grabbed by some other client, XGrabKeyboard() fails and returns AlreadyGrabbed. If x11window is not viewable, it fails and returns GrabNotViewable. If the keyboard is frozen by an active grab of another client, it fails and returns GrabFrozen. If the specified time is earlier than the last-keyboard-grab time or later than the current X server time, it fails and returns GrabInvalidTime. Otherwise, the last-keyboard-grab time is set to the specified time (CurrentTime is replaced by the current X server time).

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XtGrabKey(System.IntPtr,X11.TInt,X11.XStateMask,System.IntPtr,X11.TBoolean,X11.TInt,X11.TInt)
member.summary: Establish a passive grab (generates NO FocusIn and FocusOut events) on the keyboard.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
Specifies the KeyCode of the key to grab or AnyKey. AnyKey = (TInt)0.
Specifies the set of keymasks or AnyModifier. The mask is the bitwise inclusive OR of the valid keymask bits.
The window that shold grab the key.
Specifies a Boolean value that indicates whether the keyboard events are to be reported as usual.
Specifies further processing of pointer events. GrabModeSync or GrabModeAsync can be passed.
Specifies further processing of keyboard events. You can pass GrabModeSync or GrabModeAsync.
member.remarks: The KeyPress event is reported if all of the following conditions are true: - The keyboard is not grabbed and the specified key (which can itself be a modifier key) is logically pressed when the specified modifier keys are logically down, and no other modifier keys are logically down. - Either the x11window is an ancestor of (or is) the focus window, or the x11window is a descendant of the focus window and contains the pointer. - A passive grab on the same key combination does not exist on any ancestor of grab_window. It seems to mean: The grab window can not be a child of (or a) popup shell (override shell).

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XSync(System.IntPtr,X11.TBoolean)
member.summary: Flush the output buffer and then waits until all requests have been received and processed by the X server.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The boolean value that indicates whether XSync() discards all events on the event queue.
member.remarks: Use 'discard' set to (X11.TBoolean)1 with maximum care!!! The default is 'discard' set to (X11.TBoolean)0. Any errors generated must be handled by the error handler. For each protocol error received by Xlib.XSync() calls the client application's error handling routine (see "Using the Default Error Handlers"). Any events generated by the server are enqueued into the library's event queue.

The XQueryTree function returns the root ID, the parent window ID, a pointer to the list of child windows (NULL when there are no children), and the number of children in the list for the specified window. The children are listed in current stacking order, from bottom-most (first) to top-most (last). To free a non-NULL children list when it is no longer needed, use XFree.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The of the window whose list of children, root, parent, and number of children you want to obtain.
Returns the root window of the indicated window.
Returns the parent window of the indicated window.
Returns the [] of children of the indicated window.
Returns the number of children of the indicated window.
member.returns: XQueryTree returns 0 if it fails and !0 if it succeeds.

member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
member.remarks: XPending() is identical to XEventsQueued() with the mode QueuedAfterFlush specified.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XQLength(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Return the number of events that have been received from the X server but have not been removed from the event queue.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
member.remarks: XPending() is identical to XEventsQueued() with the mode QueuedAlready specified.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XNextEvent(System.IntPtr,X11.XEvent@)
member.summary: Copies the first event from the event queue into the specified XEvent structure and then removes it from the queue. If the event queue is empty, XNextEvent() flushes the output buffer and blocks until an event is received.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
Returns the next event in the queue.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XWindowEvent(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.TLong,X11.XEvent@)
member.summary: Search the event queue for an event that matches both the specified window and event mask.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window, that specifies the widget for whicht the next event is to obtain.
The the event mask, specifying the events to obtain.
Returns the matched event's associated structure.
member.remarks: If XWindowEvent() finds a match, it removes that event from the queue and copies it into the specified XEvent structure. The other events stored in the queue are not discarded. If a matching event is not in the queue, XWindowEvent() flushes the output buffer and blocks until one is received.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XCheckMaskEvent(System.IntPtr,X11.TLong,X11.XEvent@)
member.summary: Search the event queue. The first event that matches the specified mask will be removed and copied into the specified eventReturn structure. This function never blocks and it returns a Bool indicating if the event was returned.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The the event mask, specifying the events to observe.
Returns the matched event's associated structure.
member.returns: Returns true if an event was removed from the event queue and copied into the specified x11eventReturn structure, or false otherwise.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XCheckWindowEvent(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.TLong,X11.XEvent@)
member.summary: Search the event queue and then the events available on the server connection for the first event that matches the specified window and event mask. This function never blocks and it returns a Bool indicating if the event was returned.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The window, that specifies the widget that wants to have the event checked.
The the event mask, specifying the events to observe.
Returns the matched event's associated structure.
member.returns: If it finds a match, XCheckWindowEvent() removes that event, copies it into the specified XEvent structure, and returns True. The other events stored in the queue are not discarded. If the event you requested is not available, XCheckWindowEvent() returns False , and the output buffer will have been flushed.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XCheckIfEvent(System.IntPtr,X11.XEvent@,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Search the event queue and then any events available on the server connection for the first event that matches the specified predicate procedure. If it finds a match, XCheckIfEvent() removes the event from the queue and copies it into the client-supplied XEvent structure.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
Returns the matched event's associated structure.
Specify the punction to the procedure that is to be called to determine if the next event in the queue matches what you want.
Specifies the user-supplied argument that will be passed to the predicate procedure.
member.returns: Returns true on success, or false otherwise.
member.remarks: If the predicate procedure finds a match, this event is removed from the queue. If the predicate procedure finds no match, the output buffer will have been flushed. All earlier events stored in the queue are NOT discarded.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XCheckTypedWindowEvent(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.XEventName,X11.XEvent@)
member.summary: Search the event queue and then any events available on the server connection for the first event that matches the specified type and window. If it finds a match, XCheckTypedWindowEvent() removes the event from the queue and copies it into the client-supplied XEvent structure.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
Specify the window, to search an event for.
Specify the event type to search for.
Returns the matched event's associated structure.
member.returns: Returns true on success, or false otherwise.
member.remarks: If XCheckTypedWindowEvent() finds a match, this event is removed from the queue. If XCheckTypedWindowEvent() finds no match, the output buffer will have been flushed. All earlier events stored in the queue are NOT discarded.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XFilterEvent(X11.XEvent@,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Filter X events for an input method.
member.param: Specifies the event to filter.
Specifies the window for which the filter is to be applied. If the window argument is None, method applies the filter to the window specified in the structure.
member.returns: Returns true if some input method has filtered the event and the client should discard the event, or false otherwise and the client should continue processing the event. If a keyboard grab has occurred in the client and true is returned (event has been filtered), the client should ungrab the keyboard.
member.remarks: The window argument is provided so that layers above Xlib, that do event redirection, can indicate to which window an event has been redirected.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XPeekEvent(System.IntPtr,X11.XEvent@)
member.summary: Return the first event from the event queue, but do not remove the event from the queue.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
Returns the matched event's associated structure.
member.remarks: If the queue is empty, XPeekEvent() flushes the output buffer and blocks until an event is received. It then copies the event into the client-supplied XEvent structure without removing it from the event queue.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XSendEvent(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.TBoolean,X11.TLong,X11.XEvent@)
member.summary: Identify the destination window, determine which clients should receive the specified event, ignore any active grabs and add the specified event to the output buffer.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The "destination window" the event is to be sent to, or "PointerWindow" (the window currently containing the mouse pointer), or "InputFocus" (the window that currently onwns the input focus).

Determine which clients should receive the specified event. * True or false with EMPTY eventMask, the event is sent to the client that created the "destination window". If that client no longer exists, no event is sent.

The event mask, that must match any of the event types defined for the "destination window". * True with ANY eventMask, the event is sent to every client selecting on "destination window" any of the event types in the eventMask argument. * False with ANY eventMask and NO clients have selected the event, that is sent, on "destination window" the "destination window" is replaced with the closest ancestor of "destination window".
The event that is to be sent (to be added to the output buffer).
member.returns: Nonzero on success, or zero otherwise (if the conversion to wire protocol format failed).
member.remarks: MUST NOT BE CALLED ON A DIFFERENT THREAD!

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XInstallColormap(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Install the specified colormap for its associated screen.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The colormap to associate to a screen.
member.remarks: All windows associated with this colormap immediately display with true colors. To associate a windos with this colormap during creation use XCreateWindow, XCreateSimpleWindow or assign the colormap later using XChangeWindowAttributes, or XSetWindowColormap.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XUninstallColormap(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Removes the specified colormap from the required list for its screen.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The colormap to remove from the screen.
member.remarks: As a result, the specified colormap might be uninstalled, and the X server might implicitly install or uninstall additional colormaps. Which colormaps get installed or uninstalled is server-dependent except that the required list must remain installed. If the specified colormap becomes uninstalled, the X server generates a ColormapNotify event on each window that has that colormap. In addition, for every other colormap that is installed or uninstalled as a result of a call to XUninstallColormap(), the X server generates a ColormapNotify event on each window that has that colormap.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XFreeColormap(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Delete the association between the colormap resource ID and the colormap and frees the colormap storage. However, this function has no effect on the default colormap for a screen.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The colormap to be freed.
member.remarks: If the specified colormap is an installed map for a screen, it is uninstalled (see XUninstallColormap). If the specified colormap is defined as the colormap for a window (by XCreateWindow(), XSetWindowColormap(), or XChangeWindowAttributes()), XFreeColormap() changes the colormap associated with the window to None and generates a ColormapNotify event. X does not define the colors displayed for a window with a colormap of None.

member.name: M:X11.X11lib.XAllocColor(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,X11.XColor@)
member.summary: Allocate a read-only colormap entry corresponding to the closest RGB value supported by the hardware. XAllocColor() returns the pixel value of the color closest to the specified RGB elements supported by the hardware and returns the RGB value actually used. The corresponding colormap cell is read-only. Multiple clients that request the same effective RGB value can be assigned the same read-only entry, thus allowing entries to be shared. When the last client deallocates a shared cell, it is deallocated. XAllocColor() does not use or affect the flags in the XColor structure.
member.param: The display pointer, that specifies the connection to the X server.
The colormap to use for nearest read-only color cell allocation.
The color to allocate the nearest read-only color cell for.
member.returns: Nonzero on success, or zero otherwise.
member.remarks: !!!USE XAllocExactNamedColor() or XAllocExactNamedColor() FOR APPLICATIONS!!!
